# Day 1152

![[https://x.com/ConorChepenik/status/1923910776349245757](https://x.com/ConorChepenik/status/1923910776349245757)](https://miro.medium.com/0*mqjT9tx76_2KVmeB)

I watched _Disney's Mufasa: The Lion King_ tonight. At its core, the film isn't about power. It is about restraint. It argues, quietly but forcefully, that your response to betrayal defines you more than the betrayal itself. Mufasa had every reason to rage. Instead he chose mercy, not because the world deserved it, but because he refused to become like it. That's the razor's edge between a king and a tyrant.

Loyalty, too, gets rewritten. Rafiki, Sarabi, Zazu - they don't follow Mufasa because of blood or lineage. They follow because of who he is when no one's watching. Integrity can't be inherited. It has to be earned, lived, and proved.

What makes Mufasa unforgettable is what could've broken him. Abandoned. Powerless. Built for bitterness. But he chose kindness even when it cost him. Scar saw power as entitlement. Mufasa treated it as responsibility.

In the end, real power isn't in the roar. It's in the silence that follows when even your enemies lean in to listen.

5/17/25

Conor Jay Chepenik
